revision.text:
{{also|yen|yên|yến|yeñ|yeŋ}} ==English== ===Etymology=== From {{bor|en|cmn|-}} {{zh-l|燕|tr=Yān}}, cf. [[Wade-Giles]] romanization: ''Yen¹''. ===Proper noun=== {{en-proper noun}} # {{alternative form of|en|Yan}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=1739 |origyear=1735 |last=Du Halde |first=P. |authorlink=Jean-Baptiste Du Halde |chapter=Geographical Obſervations on the Kingdom of ''Corea'' |title=The General History Of China |url=https://archive.org/details/dli.pahar.0011/ |volume=IV |edition=Second |OCLC=51344000 |page=388 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/dli.pahar.0011/page/388/ |text=[...]Nothing but War was to be ſeen among ſo many different States, and their mutual Invaſions reduced the Empire into ſeven great Kingdoms, which were called ''Tſin'', ''Tſou'', '''''Yen''''', ''Tchao'', ''Han'', ''Iſi'', ''Ouei'': The Kingdom of '''''Yen''''', which at that time comprehended no more than the preſent Province of ''Petche li'', made itſelf very ſoon Maſter of the Province of ''Leao tong'', and by puſhing on its Conqueſts by degrees towards the Eaſt, ''Corea'' was at laſt brought under the Authority and wife Government of ''Tchen pen'': This Kingdom for a long time withſtood the ambitious Attempts of the King of ''Tſin'', called ''Tſin vang'', but at laſt it fell under his Power as the other ſix had done: ''Hi vang'', King of '''''Yen''''' and of ''Corea'', was defeated, taken and killed in the Year 259 before the Birth of Chriſt, according to the Chineſe Hiſtory, and ''Tſin vang'' was acknowledged for Emperor of all ''China'' by the Name of ''Tſin chi hoang ti''.}} #* {{quote-journal |en |year=1849 |month=August |title=Annals of Confucius; or Chronology and Geography of the Chun Ts'iu |journal={{w|The Chinese Repository}} |url=https://archive.org/details/chineserepositor1881unse/ |volume=XVIII |issue=8 |oclc=1554371 |page=397 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/chineserepositor1881unse/page/397/ |text=9. ''Kingdom of'' '''''Yen''''' {{lang|zh|燕}}
''Táking'' situated in lat. 39° 54' N., long. 116° 28' E., one of the districts of Shuntien fú in Chihlí, now occupies the site of the capital of the ancient kingdom of '''Yen''', the most northern part of the empire under the reign of the Chau dynasty.}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=1962 |last=Cottrell |first=Leonard |authorlink=Leonard Cottrell |title=The Tiger of Chʻin: The Dramatic Emergence of China as a Nation |url=https://archive.org/details/tigerofchindrama00cott/ |publisher={{w|Holt Reinhart and Winston}} |LCCN=62-8352 |OCLC=760597604 |OL=5848802M |pages=3-4 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/tigerofchindrama00cott/page/3/ |text=At that time, twenty-two centuries ago, a gentleman named Ching K'o was getting scandalously drunk in the market place of the capital of '''Yen''', a feudal state in northwest China which owed nominal allegiance to the Son of Heaven (''i.e.'', the emperor) though, in fact, there was no unified Chinese state.}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=2001 |last=Fetherling |first=George |authorlink=George Fetherling |chapter=CHING K'o |title=The Book of Assassins |url=https://archive.org/details/bookofassassinsb0000feth/ |year_published=2006 |location=[[Edison]], NJ |publisher=Castle Books |ISBN=978-0-7858-2181-6 |OCLC=70170972 |OL=8103880M |page=98 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/bookofassassinsb0000feth/page/98/ |text=The remaining major kingdoms (Han, Ch'u, Chao, '''Yen''' and Ch'i) searched for a means to stop the aggressive Ch'in, who appeared to have more in common witht he Hsiung-nu than with the Chinese.
The solution seemed to appear in the kingdom of '''Yen''' with the arrival of Ching K’o in 237.}} #* {{quote-book |en |url=https://archive.org/details/isbn_9780465021451/ |year=2011 |title=Ancient Chinese Warfare |author=Ralph D. Sawyer |publisher={{w|Basic Books}} |ISBN=978-0-465-02145-1 |LCCN=2010051391 |OCLC=657595552 |OL=26042178M |page=46 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/isbn_9780465021451/page/46/ |text=Numbering among those that comprised a virtual defensive line along the 42nd degree of latitude, where the state of '''Yen''' would construct its border wall in the Warring States period, it dates to the late Shang or very early Chou and typifies settlements that fully exploit riverside locations and natural ravines while being oriented to open vistas.}} ====Translations==== {{trans-see|Yan}} ===Anagrams=== * {{anagrams|en|a=eny|-yne|NYE|Ney|Nye|eny|ney|nye}} ---- ==German== {{wikipedia|lang=de}} ===Pronunciation=== * {{audio|de|De-at-Yen.ogg|Audio (Austria)}} * {{audio|de|De-Yen.ogg|Audio}} ===Noun=== {{head|de|noun|g=m}} # [[yen]] (unit of Japanese currency) ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}} {{C|de|Currency}}
